topic.title: IPFS, Future of the web?
topic.body:
Can IPFS replace the HTTP(s)?
What is your opinion?

1620417095_17ufjt7e9DRsavS6AADWoGpiutSp8.body:
use veracrypt or gnu-privacy-guard(known as gpg).
TrueCrypt isn't FOSS or OSS.

> [xcape2net](#comment_848_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): NO, Truecrypt is not FOSS or OSS, but it has passed two independent audits.

Right, but Truecrypt is a discontinued project
VeraCrypt is a fork of TrueCrypt, much better and safer.

> [xcape2net](#comment_850_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): The problem with encryption software that has been shown to be true over and over again is that it can be compromised in subtle ways.   We now have a LOT of information about methods the NSA uses to compromise commercial encryption software.  The bottom line is that just because development of a software package is ongoing does NOT mean that it is more secure than Truecrypt, because the NSA injects NEW compromises into code when the old ones are detected and corrected. [...]

Actually it means that.
VeraCrypt is safer than TrueCrypt because it have less security issues.
VeraCrypt fixed lots of known security problems witch still exist on TrueCrypt and not only NSA, anybody can use them to attack to you.

For example:
VeraCrypt is secure from "cold boot attack" but TrueCrypt is not.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VeraCrypt#Security_improvements

> [xcape2net](#comment_852_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): None of those are significant issues.    However, I agree that Veracrypt having SHA-256 is nice.  A cold boot attack works because of hardware issues, not software.  And it only works when the attacker has physical access to a running computer or a computer that has been shut down just seconds before and still holds data in RAM. [...]

If NSA cannot crack the TruCrypt they should not be able to crack VeraCrypt.
VeraCrypt uses safer encryption algorithms.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VeraCrypt#Algorithms
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TrueCrypt#Algorithms

1620574964_1C6gAPEiSgWRPes1bmpFhWcKGyyT2.body:
Thanks everyone to sharing your opinion here.
I have same opinion but i think the future is for decentralized/distributed networks because  of few things:
1. surveillance will get worst and people will want to have their privacy right.
2. computing power will increase.
3. censorship.

For now this networks are not easy to use, they're not fast, they require lots of computing power, but i think this issues will get fixed in the future.
